title: 105_s314
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE." is a concise statement indicating the beginning of a section with a short title. The Act titled "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget by the end of the third quarter of each fiscal year. The lists must include the fiscal year when the activity first appeared on the list. The Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998 mandates executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The lists must include the fiscal year when the activity first appeared, the number of employees needed, and the contact person for more information. The Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998 requires executive agencies to submit lists of activities to the Office of Management and Budget, including the number of employees needed and a contact person for more information. The Director of OMB reviews and consults with agency heads on the final list for each fiscal year, which is then made publicly available. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget reviews and consults with executive agency heads on the final list of activities for each fiscal year, which is then made publicly available. Upon completion of the review and consultation, the executive agency head transmits the list to Congress and makes it public. The Office of Management and Budget Director publishes a notice in the Federal Register. Any changes to the list due to challenges must be promptly made public. The executive agency shall promptly publish in the Federal Register a notice when the list is available to the public. Any changes to the list must be made public and transmitted to Congress, with a notice published in the Federal Register. Within a reasonable time after publishing a notice of the public availability of a list, the executive agency must review the listed activities and use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source for those activities. Under subsection (c), the head of the executive agency must review activities on the list and use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance for this process. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance for the administration of contracting with a private sector source for executive agency activities, ensuring realistic and fair cost comparisons. When deciding whether to contract with a private sector source for executive agency activities, the head of the agency must compare costs and ensure all expenses are considered, including quality assurance, technical monitoring, liability insurance, and overhead costs. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. Interested party is defined as a private sector source with a direct economic interest in performing the activity. An interested party, in relation to an activity mentioned in subsection (a), is defined as a private sector source that is an actual or potential offeror for a contract or agreement to perform the activity and has a direct economic interest that would be negatively impacted by not procuring the activity from a private sector source. Additionally, it includes representatives of business or professional associations with members who are private sector sources as described in paragraph (1). An interested party for an activity is a private sector source or a representative of a business association with a direct economic interest in procuring the activity. This includes officers or employees of organizations within an executive agency that are offerors for the activity, as well as the head of a labor organization with members involved in the offeror organizations. An interested party for an activity can be a private sector source or a representative of a business association with a direct economic interest. This includes officers or employees of organizations within an executive agency that are offerors for the activity, as well as the head of a labor organization with members involved in the offeror organizations. Challenges to a list must be submitted to the executive agency within 30 days of its publication, and a decision must be made within 28 days of receiving the challenge. Within 30 days of the list's publication, a challenge must be submitted to the executive agency. Within 28 days of receiving the challenge, an official designated by the agency must decide on the challenge and notify the party submitting it, including an explanation of the right to appeal. Upon receiving a challenge, an official from the executive agency must decide on it and notify the party submitting the challenge with a written explanation of the decision and the right to appeal. Interested parties have 10 days to appeal an adverse decision to the head of the executive agency. The head must make a decision on the appeal within 10 days. An interested party may appeal an adverse decision to the head of the executive agency within 10 days. The head of the agency must decide on the appeal within 10 days and provide a written notification with the rationale for the decision. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, as defined in title 5 of the United States Code. Exceptions include the General Accounting Office and Government corporations. An independent establishment, as defined in title 5 of the United States Code, is exempt from this Act. This exemption also applies to the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, and nonappropriated funds instrumentalities. Government controlled corporation, nonappropriated funds instrumentality, and certain depot-level maintenance and repair of the Department of Defense are defined in specific sections of the United States Code. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Federal Government source" refers to any organization within an executive agency using Federal Government employees for an activity. An "inherently governmental function" is a function requiring performance by Federal Government employees due to its intimate relation to the public interest. The term "inherently governmental function" refers to activities that require discretion or value judgments by Federal Government employees, including interpreting and executing US laws. The term "inherently governmental function" involves making value judgments and decisions for the Federal Government, including interpreting and executing US laws to bind the United States to certain actions and protect its interests. The term "inherently governmental function" involves binding the United States to certain actions, protecting its interests, affecting private persons' life, liberty, or property, and controlling officers or employees of the United States. The term "inherently governmental function" involves actions that bind the United States, protect its interests, affect private persons' life, liberty, or property, and control officers or employees of the United States. The term "inherently governmental function" involves actions that bind the United States, protect its interests, affect private persons' life, liberty, or property, and control officers or employees of the United States. It does not normally include gathering information for or providing advice to Federal Government officials, or any primarily ministerial function. The term "inherently governmental function" excludes functions like gathering information for or providing advice to Federal Government officials, and primarily ministerial functions such as building security, mail operations, and housekeeping. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1998.
